channel.title: cata-list
channel.description: Useful lists of some of the best info, media, tools, and quotes for those who seek to understand and improve this world.

item.title: The Heretical Impulse: Zamyatin and Orwell
item.description: I In a 1931 letter to Joseph Stalin, Russian novelist Yevgeny Zamyatin adopted a respectful tone by way of introduction: 'My name is probably known to you.' The author of We, the dystopian science fiction novel that influenced Aldous Huxley's Brave New World and George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four…

item.title: Race and Social Panic at Haverford: A Case Study in Educational Dysfunction
item.description: 'You have continued to stand as an individual that seems to turn a blind eye to the stuff that's going on, as a black woman that is in the [college] administration,' said the first-year Haverford College student. 'I came to this institution'—and here she pauses for a moment, apparently fighting back…

item.title: Elon Musk Says SpaceX Will Attempt Uncrewed Mars Flight in Two Years, Human Landing in Four to Six
item.description: SpaceX founder and CEO Elon Musk was given an award from media giant Axel Springer on Tuesday, and he sat down to provide a wide-ranging interview that covered topics including space, Tesla, AI and even underpopulation. Musk addressed SpaceX's Mars ambitions first, providing current timelines…

item.title: DeepMind's Superhuman Intelligence
item.description: The solving of a 50-year scientific problem takes computers a step closer to 'true creativity'

item.title: Aftermarket Truck Mods Pollute as Much as 9 Million Extra Pickups
item.description: The EPA estimates 550,000 medium pickup trucks have disabled emissions controls.

item.title: 'Tis the Season: Congress Looks to Sneak in Unconstitutional Copyright Reform Bill Into 'Must Pass' Spending Bill
item.description: If you have to sneak your transformational copyright bill into a 'must pass' government spending bill, it seems fairly evident that you know the bill is bad. Earlier we talked about how the White House is trying to slip a Section 230 repeal...

item.title: Public Defender Tales: Innocent, But Fined
item.description: The state of Iowa collects millions of dollars in fines from people whose charges were dismissed. There's also a Catch-22: financially, you're better off guilty

item.description: How can Democrats and allied media outlets credibly oppose unhinged conspiracy theories and attacks on U.S. election legitimacy while empowering its worst purveyors?

item.description: If racism is about prejudice and power, where does that leave high-achieving minorities?

item.description: Iran has blamed Israel for the attack, and pledged retaliation.

item.title: Guns, Drugs and Viral Content: Welcome to Cartel TikTok
item.description: Mexico is set to shatter another murder record, but that grim reality is nowhere to be seen on the TikTok videos that go viral by showcasing drug cartel culture.

item.description: This is the story of our effort to publish a paper that threatens academia.

item.title: Most Americans Object to Government Tracking of Their Activities Through Cellphones
item.description: A new survey found widespread concern among Americans about government tracking of their whereabouts through their digital devices, with an overwhelming majority saying that a warrant should be required to obtain such data.

item.description: The Agency knew that their best asset for selling their wars was Barack Obama -- the same reason so many in the security state were eager to get rid of Donald Trump.

item.title: As Cities Curb Surveillance, Baltimore Police Took to the Air
item.description: In a program that overcame three court challenges this year, planes with high-tech cameras circled the city up to 40 hours a week.

item.title: Microsoft's New 'Productivity Score' Gamifies Workplace Surveillance
item.description: The company's newest feature is facing heavy criticism for allowing bosses to track how their employees use Microsoft's suite of tools, such as how frequently they send emails, collaborate in shared documents, or have their camera on during virtual meetings.

item.title: The Ethics of Rebooting the Dead
item.description: The notion of resurrecting people as digital entities is becoming less hypothetical. But just because something can be done, doesn't always mean it should.

item.title: How the Criminal Justice System Fails People With Mental Illness
item.description: 'I found your baby,' Michelle Durden recalls the police officer saying after her son went missing. 'He's alive. And he's in jail.'

item.title: This Squishy 3D-Printed Human Heart Feels Like the Real Thing
item.description: A clever technique allows scientists to scan a heart and reconstruct it in a soup of gelatin. It's like making jello, only way more useful for surgeons.

item.title: Psilocybin & Migraine: First of Its Kind Trial Reports Promising Results
item.description: A first-of-its-kind exploratory study, led by researchers from Yale School of Medicine, has found a single dose of the psychedelic psilocybin can reduce migraine frequency by 50 percent for a least two weeks. The preliminary trial was small, with follow-up work necessary to validate the results,…
